questions.hint: This event occurred at the level of direct contact between the surgeon and the patient and had an immediate impact.

questions.text: You are caring for a 36-year-old man who is admitted to hospital for a cocaine overdose. On admission, he is agitated and his blood pressure is 210/150 mm Hg. You write an order for intravenous phentolamine 5.0 mg and diazepam 2.5 mg to be given every 15 minutes. Three hours later, the patient becomes unconscious and his blood pressure is 70/50 mm Hg. It is determined that, due to an error, the patient received ten times the prescribed dose of one of the medications. Which one of the following measures would have most likely prevented this medication error?

choices.text: Clinical decision support system.
Multicompartment medication device.
Medication reconciliation.
Tall man lettering.
Computerized provider order entry.

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A clinical decision support system (CDSS) generates computerized recommendations or alerts based on patient information to prevent ordering errors. Examples of ordering errors include prescribing a drug that is contraindicated (e.g., due to drug interactions or drug allergies) and a failure to prescribe the correct dose based on weight, renal dysfunction, or hepatic dysfunction. In this case, the medication error occurred as a result of a trailing zero during transcribing, which would not have been prevented by a CDSS.

B) INCORRECT:

A multicompartment medication device is recommended for patients in ambulatory settings taking multiple medications to help prevent administration errors and improve medication safety and adherence. In this case, the medication error occurred at the transcribing stage and led to the misinterpretation of a trailing zero, which would not have been prevented by a multicompartment medication device.

C) INCORRECT:

Medication reconciliation is a measure used to prevent ordering errors during a transition of care and helps to avoid inconsistencies between the patient's previous medication and the new medication prescribed. In this case, the medication error occurred at the transcribing stage and led to the misinterpretation of a trailing zero, which would not have been prevented by medication reconciliation.

D) INCORRECT:

Tall man lettering is a strategy used to prevent dispensing errors related to medications that look or sound alike (e.g., buPROPion vs. busPIRone). In this case, the medication error occurred at the transcribing stage and led to the misinterpretation of a trailing zero, which would not have been prevented by tall man lettering.

E) CORRECT:

Paper-based systems in which medication orders are handwritten are prone to transcribing errors, which can result in the recipient of the order not being able to properly read and interpret the prescription. In this case, as the physician determined that the patient received ten times the prescribed dose, the transcribing error was most likely due to the misinterpretation of a trailing zero after a decimal point. Trailing zeros are part of the Institute for Safe Medication Practices' (ISMP) “Do Not Use” list, which provides recommendations on best practices in medication safety. To prevent transcribing errors, many Canadian hospitals have adopted electronic prescribing and computerized provider order entry (CPOE) systems, which also help to prevent ordering errors by often being combined with clinical decision support systems. If a CPOE system has not been adopted and the health care facility maintains a paper-based system, the use of standardized abbreviations and writing styles, along with having an intermediary such as a clinical pharmacist or pharmacy technician review and interpret prescriptions, can help prevent transcribing errors.

Key learning point: Computerized provider order entry reduces medication errors by eliminating handwriting misinterpretations and transcription mistakes, such as dosing errors from unclear decimal points.
questions.hint: Medication errors can occur at the stages of ordering (prescribing), transcribing, dispensing, and administering a drug. This patient's medication error is most likely due to faulty transcribing and led to the misinterpretation of a trailing zero.

questions.text: You are working with the administrative directors of a provincial health authority in Ontario who wish to improve the quality of cardiac care in their affiliated hospital cardiology units while maintaining fiscal responsibility. To establish a baseline for quality of care, they collect data on the number of Royal College-certified cardiologists, provider-to-patient ratios, and nursing hours per patient per day in each cardiology department. Which of the following terms best describes the measures used by the health authority to assess the quality of care?

choices.text: Outcome.
Composite.
Process.
Structural.
Balancing.

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Outcome measures assess the final impact of services provided by a health care facility on patients' health status. An example of an outcome measure would be the 30-day mortality rate of patients who are admitted with a diagnosis of acute coronary syndrome. In this case, the directors evaluate the resources available at their facility, not the final impact of their services on patients.

B) INCORRECT:

Composite measures, which aggregate structural, process, and outcome measures in a single score, provide a comprehensive overview of a health care facility's performance. In this case, the directors evaluate only one domain of the health care quality (i.e., resources available at the facility), which is not a composite measure.

C) INCORRECT:

Process measures evaluate whether health care procedures such as diagnostic tests, treatments, and preventive care are performed in accordance with current standards. An example of a process measure would be the percentage of patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus and hypertension who are on ACE inhibitors. In this case, the directors evaluate the resources available at their facility, not the procedures per se.

D) CORRECT:

Structural measures evaluate the material, organizational, and professional resources (e.g., equipment, facilities, staff) available at a health care facility. Examples include the evaluation of the number of beds, volume of surgeries performed, usage of medication order entry systems, and provision of digital copies of health records to patients. A facility's structural characteristics affect other domains of healthcare quality, which can be assessed via process measures, outcome measures, balancing measures, and composite measures. Composite measures aggregate several types of quality measures into a single score and allow a comprehensive view of the overall performance of a health care system.

Key learning point: Structural measures in the Donabedian model assess the resources, staff, and organizational features available in a healthcare setting to support quality care.

E) INCORRECT:

Balancing measures assess whether changes in one part of a health care system have an unintended impact on another part of the system (e.g., whether readmission rates increase after an initiative to reduce the average length of stay). In this case, the directors evaluate the resources available at their health care facility, which is better described by a different term.
questions.hint: The Donabedian model identifies several types of quality measures to assess and compare different aspects of quality in a health care system.

questions.text: You are the head of a private surgical daycare clinic reviewing a recent cost-benefit analysis. The analysis suggests that purchasing multidose vials for injectable drugs may be more economical than using individual prefilled syringes. To reduce costs, the clinic pharmacy plans to switch from prefilled single-dose syringes to bulk multidose vials that must be prepared for single-use injection. An anesthesiologist expresses concern that using multidose vials could increase the risk of perioperative medication errors. If your clinic continues to purchase multidose vials, which one of the following actions is most likely to maximize patient safety?

choices.text: Drawing up and labeling of drugs in the on-site pharmacy before surgery.
Drawing up of drugs by the circulating nurse during surgery based on instructions by the anesthetist.
Drawing up of drugs by the anesthesiologist during surgery.
Drawing up and labeling of drugs by the surgeon before surgery.

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Drugs that are commonly required during surgery should be prepared beforehand and should always be readily available. Involving the on-site pharmacist is a key step to prevent drug dispensing errors. If multiple patients receive doses from the same vial (as seen in multidose vials), drug dispensing for the operating room should take place in a clean area reserved for medication preparation (e.g., a satellite pharmacy) and in an aseptic manner (e.g., using sterile syringes, disinfecting the septum before piercing the vial). Preparing drug trays with prefilled syringes in conjunction with clear labeling (e.g., with the drug's generic name and drug concentration) using standardized printed labels maximizes patient safety by reducing the risk of product mix-ups and dispensing errors. The label may also include the date, time, pharmacist's name, and the patient's name and date of birth.

Key learning point: Preparing and labeling single-use syringes from multidose vials in the on-site pharmacy before surgery, using standardized printed labels, maximizes patient safety by minimizing medication errors and contamination risk.

B) INCORRECT:

Circulating nurses have a number of responsibilities during surgery, such as providing additional equipment when needed, and are often responsible for more than one surgical team. Therefore, there would be an increased risk of attentional capture and skill-based errors if the circulating nurse prepared the drugs; a different person should be designated for drug dispensing. In addition, drugs that are commonly required during surgery should be prepared prior to surgery and always readily available.

C) INCORRECT:

Anesthesiologists have a high cognitive workload and carry out multiple important tasks during surgery (e.g., administering and managing anesthesia, monitoring and controlling patients' vital functions and level of consciousness). Therefore, there would be an increased risk of attentional capture and skill-based errors if the anesthesiologist was responsible for drawing up drugs during surgery. Moreover, the anesthesiologist works in the immediate patient area, and dispensing drugs in this area is not recommended, as it increases the risk of contamination.

D) INCORRECT:

Before surgery, the surgeon is responsible for preparing the operation (e.g., reviewing the patient's records, confirming their diagnosis and thus the indication for the planned procedure). Additionally, the surgeon needs to scrub up and, as the leader of the surgical team, is also responsible for briefing the team and adherence to the universal protocol. The operating surgeon is not responsible for drawing up and labeling drugs.
questions.hint: The use of multidose vials instead of prefilled single-dose syringes increases the risk of medication dispensing errors and contamination.

questions.text: A 62-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department because of a 1-week history of nausea and vomiting. She also has had intermittent fevers and headaches during the past 5 weeks. A lumbar puncture is performed, and cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) is collected for analysis. On the way to the laboratory, the physician loses the CSF specimens. The physician decides that a repeat lumbar puncture should be performed. Before giving consent for the second procedure, the patient asks what the results are from the specimens obtained earlier. Which of the following responses by the physician is the most appropriate?

choices.text: "There were just too many patients for us to keep track of today. I am so sorry, but I misplaced the specimens."
"I was unable to obtain results from the earlier tests because I misplaced the specimens. I sincerely apologize for the mistake."
"I sincerely apologize; I misplaced the specimens. Thankfully, this is not a big issue because I can easily obtain more fluid."
"Unfortunately, I was not able to get enough fluid in the specimens to perform the tests."
"I sincerely apologize; the lab seems to have lost the specimens I obtained earlier."

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Although this response does disclose that the physician lost the specimens, it is inappropriate because it makes an unprofessional excuse and implies that the error was unavoidable.

B) CORRECT:

This response is the most appropriate way of disclosing the medical error to the patient. Disclosure of medical errors involves clearly admitting the error, describing the nature of the error, and expressing personal regret or apology. Timely, full disclosure of errors is beneficial for the physician-patient relationship and patient safety.

Key learning point: Appropriate medical error disclosure involves acknowledging the mistake, objectively explaining what happened, and expressing a sincere apology.

C) INCORRECT:

Although this response does disclose that the physician lost the specimens, it is inappropriate because it minimizes the gravity of the situation. Physicians should disclose errors in objective terms and refrain from placing a value judgment on the significance of the error because each patient will have a unique response.

D) INCORRECT:

This response is inappropriate because it fails to disclose that a medical error has occurred. In addition, it falsely claims that the CSF collected from the first lumbar puncture was inadequate.

E) INCORRECT:

Although this response does disclose that the specimens were lost, it is inappropriate because it falsely blames the laboratory. Optimal error disclosure involves clearly admitting that an error has occurred and truthfully stating the course of events that led to the error.
questions.hint: The loss of the first CSF specimens constitutes a medical error.

questions.text: An emergency department implements a quality improvement initiative to reduce left-without-being-seen (LWBS) rates, currently at 8%. The team hypothesizes that bedside registration will decrease wait times and improve patient satisfaction. After testing this intervention during day shifts for one month, they collect data showing that LWBS rates decreased to 5% and patient satisfaction scores improved from 3.2 to 4.1 out of 5. They also note that registration clerks report increased workload and some patients express confusion about the new process. What is the most appropriate next step?

choices.text: Begin planning a new Plan-Do-Study-Act cycle to address registration clerk workload
Extend the pilot period to include night shifts before making decisions
Abandon the intervention due to staff concerns and patient confusion
Analyze the results against their original hypothesis and determine if the intervention should be adopted
Implement bedside registration across all shifts immediately

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Planning a new Plan-Do-Study-Act cycle is appropriate after completing the current cycle through the Act phase, not immediately after data collection.

B) INCORRECT:

Extending the pilot would be part of a modified Do phase of the Plan-Do-Study-Act cycle, but the current data should first be analyzed in the Study phase to determine if extension is necessary.

C) INCORRECT:

Abandoning the intervention without proper analysis bypasses the Study phase of the Plan-Do-Study-Act cycle entirely and ignores the positive outcomes achieved in the primary metrics.

D) CORRECT:

Correct -- This represents the Study phase of the Plan-Do-Study-Act cycle. Data collected during the Do phase are analyzed, and outcomes are compared with predictions and hypotheses to assess the impact on health care quality before deciding on implementation.

E) INCORRECT:

Implementation occurs during the Act phase of the Plan-Do-Study-Act cycle, but only after completing the Study phase to analyze whether the intervention was successful and should be adopted or modified.

questions.text: A 52-year-old man presents to the ED with chest discomfort that resolves after initial evaluation and treatment. He later tells the charge nurse that the physician "ignored his pain" and "didn't explain what was happening." The nurse notifies the treating team of the patient's concerns. The patient appears calm but frustrated when approached. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step?

choices.text: Document the interaction thoroughly and refer the patient to hospital administration for formal complaint processing
Acknowledge his concerns, actively listen to his perspective, and explain the care provided using empathetic communication
Reassure the patient that his test results were normal and proceed with standard discharge instructions
Have the charge nurse address his concerns while continuing with other patient care responsibilities
Provide a detailed written summary of all interventions performed during his ED visit

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

While documentation is important, immediate referral to administration without first attempting direct communication misses the opportunity for immediate service recovery. This approach does not address the patient's immediate emotional needs and may exacerbate his frustration.

B) CORRECT:

Correct – This approach aligns with evidence-based service recovery principles. Patient concerns should be acknowledged, active listening should be employed, and empathetic communication should be used to explain the care provided. Direct engagement can prevent escalation and improve patient satisfaction while maintaining the therapeutic relationship.

C) INCORRECT:

Simply providing reassurance about test results dismisses the patient's emotional experience and communication concerns. This response does not validate his feelings and may exacerbate his frustration by appearing dismissive of the patient's perspective.

D) INCORRECT:

Delegating complaint management entirely to nursing staff neglects the physician's responsibility for direct patient communication. While nursing support is valuable, the attending physician should personally address concerns about clinical interactions and communication.

E) INCORRECT:

Providing written documentation without verbal communication and acknowledgment of his concerns is impersonal and may appear defensive. This approach does not demonstrate empathy or address the patient's feelings about the interaction, which are central to the complaint.

questions.text: A 42-year-old man submits a formal written complaint to hospital administration regarding his recent emergency department visit for chest pain, stating that he felt his concerns were dismissed by the nursing staff. The complaint is forwarded to the emergency department medical director for review. The medical record demonstrates appropriate clinical assessment, diagnostic workup, and disposition. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial response to this complaint?

choices.text: Forward the complaint directly to the hospital's risk management department without departmental review
Meet with the involved nursing staff privately and advise them to avoid further contact with the complainant
Acknowledge the patient's concern, conduct an objective review with staff, and provide a written response
Send a standardized letter stating that the medical care met appropriate standards and the matter is resolved
Modify the existing nursing documentation to better reflect patient interactions before responding to the complaint

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

While risk management consult may be appropriate for formal complaints, exclusive referral without departmental investigation does not demonstrate effective leadership engagement and accountability. Emergency department leaders must actively participate in complaint review processes to identify system issues, implement quality improvement measures, and foster a culture of continuous improvement. This approach misses opportunities for meaningful service recovery and staff education.

B) INCORRECT:

Restricting communication between staff and patients undermines fundamental principles of transparency and open dialogue essential for addressing patient dissatisfaction in the emergency department setting. This approach violates ethical standards of patient-centered care, prevents valuable service recovery opportunities, and may escalate rather than resolve the underlying concerns. Effective leadership requires creating environments where staff can engage constructively with patient feedback.

C) CORRECT:

Correct – This structured approach demonstrates appropriate complaint management by acknowledging the patient's perspective, conducting an objective investigation with involved staff, and providing transparent communication. This methodology aligns with quality improvement principles by treating complaints as opportunities for system enhancement, promotes ethical leadership through accountability, and supports evidence-based service recovery strategies that can prevent similar incidents in the future.

D) INCORRECT:

Generic responses fail to address individual patient concerns and may appear dismissive or defensive to complainants, potentially damaging the emergency department's reputation and patient trust. Effective complaint resolution requires personalized, empathetic communication that demonstrates genuine consideration of patient experiences. This approach misses quality improvement opportunities and falls short of patient satisfaction standards that may be important for local hospital performance metrics.

E) INCORRECT:

Altering medical documentation after formal complaint submission constitutes inappropriate and potentially fraudulent practice that violates fundamental ethical and legal standards. Emergency department leaders must maintain documentation integrity to ensure patient safety, legal compliance, and professional accountability. All original documentation should remain intact, with any necessary clarifications made through properly dated and signed addenda following established institutional policies and procedures.

questions.text: A 63-year-old man with diabetes, hypertension, and chronic kidney disease presents to the emergency department with fever, dysuria, and confusion. The emergency physician uses the electronic health record's clinical decision support system while managing this patient. Which of the following is the main advantage of clinical decision support systems in emergency medicine practice?

choices.text: They reduce diagnostic errors by providing differential diagnosis suggestions
They improve workflow efficiency by automating routine clinical tasks
They enhance clinical decision-making through integration of patient-specific data
They ensure regulatory compliance by standardizing documentation practices
They facilitate provider communication through automated notification systems

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

While some clinical decision support systems can provide diagnostic assistance, their primary function is safety enhancement rather than diagnostic support. Emergency physicians primarily rely on clinical reasoning and pattern recognition for diagnostic accuracy.

B) INCORRECT:

Clinical decision support systems typically add steps to clinical workflow through alerts and confirmations instead of automating routine tasks. Their primary benefit is safety improvement, not efficiency enhancement.

C) CORRECT:

Correct – Clinical decision support systems improve safety and decision quality by integrating real-time patient data, including medications, allergies, laboratory results, and comorbidities. This helps identify contraindications, dosing errors, and drug interactions, which support safe, evidence-based emergency care.

D) INCORRECT:

While clinical decision support systems may help standardize documentation practices, regulatory compliance is a secondary benefit. The primary function focuses on real-time clinical decision support and patient safety enhancement during active care delivery.

E) INCORRECT:

Some electronic health record platforms include messaging features, but clinical decision support systems are primarily designed to enhance decision-making accuracy, not serve as communication systems. Their value lies in analyzing patient data to prevent clinical errors.

questions.text: A 62-year-old man presents to the emergency department in cardiac arrest. Despite high-quality CPR, return of spontaneous circulation is delayed. A post-event analysis shows confusion regarding team roles, medication administration errors, and ineffective communication among team members during the resuscitation. Which of the following interventions would most effectively address these performance deficits?

choices.text: Mandatory individual review of ACLS protocols every six months
Regular team-based simulation training with structured debriefing
Implementation of electronic medication dosing alerts during cardiac arrests
Assignment of resuscitations to the most senior available physician
Retrospective chart review of prior cardiac arrest documentation

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Individual protocol review enhances individual knowledge but does not address team coordination, communication breakdowns, or role clarity issues that occur during high-stress resuscitation scenarios.

B) CORRECT:

Correct – Team-based simulation training with structured debriefing directly addresses the identified deficits by allowing teams to practice role assignment, communication strategies, and coordinated care in a controlled environment. This approach improves crisis resource management skills and team performance during actual resuscitations.

C) INCORRECT:

Electronic alerts may reduce medication errors but do not address the fundamental team performance issues of unclear roles, ineffective communication, and poor leadership and coordination that were identified in the analysis.

D) INCORRECT:

Senior physician assignment does not ensure effective team communication or clear role assignment. Leadership effectiveness depends on structured team coordination rather than individual experience level alone.

E) INCORRECT:

Chart review identifies documentation problems after the fact but does not improve real-time team performance, communication, or coordination during active resuscitation efforts.

questions.text: An emergency department identifies that door-to-antibiotic time for patients with suspected sepsis routinely exceeds national benchmarks. The quality improvement committee initiates a project using the PDSA framework. During the initial phase, the team develops a standardized sepsis alert and antibiotic order set for rapid initiation of therapy. Which of the following is the next appropriate step in the PDSA cycle?

choices.text: Review sepsis mortality data from the past year to identify long-term trends
Implement the new order set across all shifts and collect outcome data for one year
Pilot the process on one shift, collect data, and evaluate time-to-antibiotic outcomes
Conduct staff re-education on sepsis management protocols before pilot testing
Submit the new process for administrative approval and integration into hospital policy

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Reviewing sepsis mortality data from the past year provides valuable outcome information, but it should occur later in the PDSA process. The cycle emphasizes immediate data collection and analysis of the small-scale intervention before examining long-term trends. Historical trend analysis should occur after the intervention's effectiveness is demonstrated through pilot testing.

B) INCORRECT:

Implementing the new order set across all shifts without pilot testing skips the essential small-scale testing phase of the PDSA cycle. This approach risks implementing an untested process throughout the organization before its effectiveness is understood or any potential barriers are identified. PDSA methodology emphasizes testing process changes on a small scale before implementing more broadly.

C) CORRECT:

Correct – After planning and developing the intervention ("Plan") and beginning to test it ("Do"), the next step in the PDSA cycle is to analyze the collected data ("Study"). This involves measuring and monitoring outcomes, comparing results with predictions, and assessing the intervention's impact on health care quality. Small-scale pilot testing allows for controlled evaluation and refinement before broader implementation in the "Act" phase.

D) INCORRECT:

Staff education supports successful change implementation but should occur after the feasibility and benefit of the intervention has been demonstrated during pilot testing. The PDSA cycle prioritizes learning from rapid, small-scale testing rather than investing in comprehensive training before the intervention's effectiveness has been proven. Education becomes more valuable once the process has been refined based on pilot results.

E) INCORRECT:

Seeking administrative approval and policy integration is the "Act" phase of the PDSA cycle, which occurs after successful pilot testing and data analysis. This approach bypasses the critical "Study" phase, in which pilot data is analyzed to determine effectiveness and identify necessary modifications. PDSA methodology requires demonstration of the intervention's effectiveness before it is formalized into organizational policy.

questions.text: An infectious disease chairperson restricts the usage of clindamycin in a large hospital to determine if that lowers the incidence of C. difficile infections. She puts in place a requirement that an infectious disease fellow needs to approve any prescription of clindamycin. After 2 months, she reviews the hospital infection data and determines that the incidence of C. difficile infections has decreased, but not to the extent that she had hoped. Consequently, she decides to include fluoroquinolone antibiotics in the antibiotic restriction and examine the data again in another 2 months. Which of the following best describes this process?

choices.text: Plan, do, study, act cycle.
Lean process improvement.
High reliability organization.
Root cause analysis.
Failure mode and effects analysis.

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

The plan, do, study, act cycle (PDSA) is a model used to improve healthcare quality; it is the process being used by the infectious disease chairperson. The “Plan” phase consists of defining an area that needs improvement and planning potential interventions to bring about a corrective change (e.g., determining that the incidence of C. difficile infections at the hospital is too high and proposing an initiative to restrict the usage of clindamycin). The “Do” phase consists of testing the intervention (e.g., requiring that an infectious disease fellow approve any prescription of clindamycin for a 2-month period). The “Study” phase consists of assessing the impact of the intervention on the quality of healthcare (e.g., reviewing the hospital infection data). The “Act” phase consists of implementing the new intervention if the previous test showed a positive impact on healthcare quality (e.g., implementing the clindamycin restriction long-term) or restarting the cycle if the results were negative or had no significant impact (e.g., including fluoroquinolones in the antibiotic restriction).

Key learning point: The plan-do-study-act cycle is an iterative quality improvement model involving planning a change, implementing it, studying the results, and acting on findings to refine interventions.

B) INCORRECT:

Lean process improvement is a model of quality improvement in which the methods used to identify and eliminate factors that use time, energy, and resources without improving patient outcomes are continually evaluated. Lean process improvement does not describe the process used by the infectious disease chairperson.

C) INCORRECT:

High reliability organizations are organizations that have operated for a substantial period of time with outcomes being almost failure-free, despite their work carrying many potential, serious risks. It does not describe the process used by the infectious disease chairperson.

D) INCORRECT:

Root cause analysis is a retrospective analysis performed after a medical error has occurred in order to identify the (root) causes of the error and implement measures to prevent a recurrence. The components of this analysis include identifying which medical error occurred, determining why it happened, and instituting measures to try to prevent it from happening again. Root cause analysis does not describe the process used by the infectious disease chairperson.

E) INCORRECT:

Failure mode and effects analysis (FMEA) is a prospective analysis to anticipate potential risks and hazards and proactively implement measures to prevent a medical error from occurring. The components of this analysis include identification of what could go wrong and what impact it could have (failure mode), identification of why it could go wrong (failure causes), identification of the outcomes of the potential failures (failure effects), and proactive implementation of corrective measures. FMEA does not describe the process used by the infectious disease chairperson.
questions.hint: The process being used is a specific model of quality improvement.

questions.text: A 72-year-old man is admitted to the hospital because of a thrombotic stroke with right-sided weakness and dysphagia. A videofluoroscopic swallowing study shows an increased risk of aspiration. A Dobhoff feeding tube is placed, and the patient starts receiving tube feedings. Shortly after, he develops a cough and dyspnea. An x-ray of the chest shows opacification of the right lower lobe, and that the end of the Dobhoff tube is in his right lung instead of his stomach. Which of the following would most likely have prevented this medical error?

choices.text: Checklist.
Closed-loop communication.
Fishbone diagram.
Computerized physician order entry.
Mortality and morbidity review.

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Use of a standardized checklist, which includes obtaining an abdominal x-ray to determine that the tip of the Dobhoff tube is in the correct anatomical position before tube feedings are started, would most likely have prevented this medical error from occurring. Standardization is the development and implementation of standards that apply to various aspects of a process or system in order to improve reliability, efficiency, communication, and safety. Checklists, protocols, guidelines, equipment, and terminology help medical professionals to adhere to standardized procedures.

Key learning point: Standardized checklists prevent medical errors during procedures.

B) INCORRECT:

Closed-loop communication is the process of the recipient of information letting the sender of information know that the information was heard and repeating back to the sender what was heard (i.e., double-checking) to help ensure that the two participants have the same understanding of what was said. Closed-loop communication can help prevent communication errors. However, in this case, the error was not due to miscommunication between the healthcare personnel, but rather due to lack of confirmation that the Dobhoff tube was in the correct anatomical position.

C) INCORRECT:

A fishbone diagram can be used to analyze all of the potential causes of a specific error. However, a fishbone diagram relies on the same error having been made in the past in this hospital and a subsequent diagram created. It also relies on the physician to have seen and understood the diagram when placing the Dobhoff tube and ordering tube feedings.

D) INCORRECT:

Computerized physician order entry (CPOE) is the practice of entering instructions (e.g., medication orders) electronically, with the orders sent directly to the receiver. CPOE systems reduce transcription errors that might occur due to poor handwriting, ambiguous abbreviations, or other factors. However, in this case, the error was not due to an order or transcription issue but rather due to lack of confirmation that the Dobhoff tube was in the correct anatomical position.

E) INCORRECT:

A mortality and morbidity review (M&M review) is a meeting within a hospital in which a department reviews complications and deaths that have occurred within the department. The idea behind M&M reviews is to educate the attendants and try to prevent the same error from being repeated. However, an M&M review relies on the same error having been made in the past within the department and presented at an M&M review. It also relies on the physician who placed the Dobhoff tube and ordered tube feedings to have attended the review and understood and remembered the outcomes.
questions.hint: There is a standardized procedure for Dobhoff feeding tube insertion.

questions.text: A 37-year-old woman at 37 weeks' gestation is scheduled for elective cesarean section. The night before the procedure, she informs the covering resident physician that she would like to undergo a postpartum tubal ligation. The resident physician obtains informed consent for the procedure and adds the patient's request to the patient's electronic chart. The next morning, the night shift resident, who has been at the hospital for 22 hours, forgets to update the gynecological resident covering the day shift with this information. The surgical nurse, who only recently started working at the hospital, does not review the added note in the patient's chart. The gynecological resident performs the cesarean delivery, but the postpartum tubal ligation is not performed. Which one of the following is the most likely cause of the error?

choices.text: Alert fatigue.
Inadequate patient assessment.
Failed communication.
Inexperienced nurse.
Improper documentation.

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Alert fatigue is the desensitization of health care providers to alarms as a result of repeated exposure to false and/or nonactionable alarms. There is no evidence of alert fatigue in this scenario.

B) INCORRECT:

Inadequate patient assessment is a possible source of medical error, especially among physicians who are still in training, like the resident physician here. Nonetheless, there is no evidence that inadequate patient assessment is the cause of error in this case.

C) CORRECT:

Failed communication, which is a common cause of medical error, can occur as a result of poor communication between medical personnel, failure to adequately communicate with the patient and/or patient's family, failure to review medical records, and lack of standardized terminology or the use of jargon. In this case, the resident physician who covered the night shift forgot to update the gynecological resident, resulting in new clinical information not being communicated. Secondly, the surgical nurse did not review the patient's medical record, where the note about postpartum tubal ligation was added. Measures to prevent communication-related errors include the implementation of standardized handoffs, the use of standardized medical terminology and abbreviations in documentation, signouts, read-backs, timeouts, a safety culture, flat authority gradients, and teamwork training.

Key learning point: Communication failures during handoffs and inadequate review of documentation are common causes of preventable medical errors and can be mitigated through standardized processes and robust team communication practices.

D) INCORRECT:

Inexperienced healthcare personnel is a risk factor for nescient errors. Although the surgical nurse only recently started working at the hospital, there is no evidence that the error was directly related to this nurse having a lack of experience. The error in this scenario was due to the lack of a standardized handoff.

E) INCORRECT:

Improper documentation (e.g., incomplete entry of clinically relevant information, use of nonstandardized abbreviations) can cause medical errors. Because the resident physician added the patient's request to the electronic chart, improper documentation does not seem to be the cause of error here.
questions.hint: The additional clinical information regarding postpartum tubal ligation was not passed on to all healthcare personnel involved.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of blurry vision, headaches, and chest pain for the past 3 days. He takes enalapril for hypertension, but did not take his medications for a week. His pulse is 94/min and blood pressure is 202/116 mm Hg. He is admitted to the hospital for continuous cardiac monitoring, and a labetalol infusion is initiated. The next day, his blood pressure decreases to 155/92 mm Hg, and the physician directs the nurse on call to discontinue intravenous labetalol and reinitiate daily 15 mg oral enalapril treatment. Which one of the following responses is most appropriate for the nurse?

choices.text: "I will do it right away."
"I will write down the order and change the medications right after the morning rounds."
"Of course. I will discontinue the labetalol infusion and start the patient on oral enalapril."
"I will stop the labetalol infusion and put the patient on 15 mg daily oral enalapril."
"I will put the patient on an oral ACE inhibitor, QD immediately."

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

This response is ambiguous and does not allow the physician to verify that the nurse heard the information and understood it correctly.

B) INCORRECT:

This response does not allow the physician to verify that the nurse has heard and understood the medication information correctly. A comprehensive response is important to help prevent communication errors and to allow the sender of information to verify accuracy.

C) INCORRECT:

While the nurse has repeated the names and routes of medications back to the physician, there is additional information about the medication that should also be reiterated. A comprehensive response is important to allow the physician to verify that the nurse has heard and understood the information correctly.

D) CORRECT:

This statement is an example of closed-loop communication, an error prevention technique in which the listener repeats the information received back to the speaker. The nurse (i.e., the listener) reiterates the name and route of the medication to be discontinued and the name, route, dosage, and frequency of the medication to be reinitiated. Doing so allows the speaker (i.e., the physician) to verify if the information was understood correctly. Closed-loop communication is important for preventing communication errors in other situations as well, including during cardiopulmonary resuscitation, during trauma management, and in the operating room.

Key learning point: Closed-loop communication ensures accurate understanding and prevents medication errors.

E) INCORRECT:

While the nurse has generally referenced the correct medication type and frequency, this response is not specific enough for the physician to verify that the nurse has heard and understood the information correctly. A comprehensive response is important to help prevent communication errors and to allow the sender of the information to verify accuracy.
questions.hint: The most appropriate response is the one that minimizes the likelihood of medical error.

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy is brought to the office by his mother because of a 3-day history of fever, sore throat, and refusal to eat. Rapid antigen detection test for group A streptococci is positive. The physician prescribes penicillin V oral tablets. Which of the following is the most appropriate way to write the prescription?

choices.text: Penicillin, 500 mg, PO, BID, for 10 days.
Penicillin V, 500 mg, orally, twice a day, for 10 days.
Penicillin V, 25 mg/kg, orally, twice a day, as directed.
Pen-V, 500.00 mg, orally, twice a day, as directed.
Penicillin V, 25.0 mg/kg, orally, b.d.s., for 10 days.

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Drugs should be identified as specifically as possible; this prescription does not specify which type of penicillin is being prescribed. Furthermore, the use of Latin and acronyms such as “PO” (per os, which means by mouth) or “BID” (bis in die, which means twice a day) should be avoided.

B) CORRECT:

This prescription is written in precise, simple, and common language and is, therefore, least likely to result in a medication error. First, the drug is named specifically (“Penicillin V”). Second, the dosage (“500 mg”) describes the drug strength in clearly defined units and does not contain trailing zeros. Third, the route (“orally”), frequency (“twice a day”), and duration (“for 10 days”) of administration are all written in plain English; Latin, abbreviations, and acronyms should be avoided because they can be misinterpreted.

In addition, it is recommended to indicate the reason for the medication on the prescription (e.g., “Streptococcal pharyngitis”), as this introduces an additional safety checkpoint and opportunity for counseling for pharmacists and collaborating providers, and reminds the patient of the drug's purpose. Other instructions typically provided on prescriptions include the number of medication units to be dispensed and the number of refills permitted before the patient's next follow-up.

Key learning point: To write safe prescriptions, use generic drug names, precise dosages without trailing zeros, and plain English language for route, frequency, and duration.

C) INCORRECT:

Although pediatric dosages can be written using the units “mg/kg,” the use of vague statements such as “as directed” should be avoided.

D) INCORRECT:

In general, it is recommended to use generic (e.g., “Penicillin V”) rather than commercial drug names (e.g., “Pen-V”) on prescriptions to avoid conflicts of interest and decrease the risk of confusing similar-sounding medications. Furthermore, the use of vague statements such as “as directed” should be avoided. The use of trailing zeros as in “500.00 mg” should be avoided because the dosage can be easily misread (e.g., 50000 mg), which can result in serious adverse events.

E) INCORRECT:

The use of trailing zeros as in “25.0 mg/kg” should be avoided because the dosage can be easily misread (e.g., 250 mg/kg), which can result in serious adverse events. Moreover, the use of Latin and acronyms such as “b.d.s” (bis die sumendum, which means twice a day) is discouraged.
questions.hint: Physicians should prescribe medications as precisely and simply as possible in order to prevent errors and maximize patient safety.

questions.text: A 16-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department because of a surgical site infection (SSI) 20 days after a laparoscopic appendectomy. The physician on duty recalls that she saw a different patient with similar symptoms earlier this week, and she decides to look at the hospital statistics for SSI incidence. She notes that at least five patients developed SSI in the pediatric unit during the last month and that all of them received a lower dose of preoperative cefoxitin than is recommended by current guidelines. Which one of the following is the most appropriate next step to prevent the recurrence of such a mistake in the future?

choices.text: Conduct a root cause analysis.
Plan a retrospective cohort study.
Implement a multilayered safety system.
Perform a failure mode and effects analysis.

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

A root cause analysis is a retrospective method that has the goal to prevent the recurrence of medical errors. The first step of this method is the identification of the medical error (e.g., lower dose of preoperative cefoxitin administered than is recommended by current guidelines), followed by the investigation of individual factors (sharp-end errors) and systemic factors (blunt-end errors) that contributed to the error (e.g., through a fishbone diagram of causes leading to patients developing SSI). After this, possible measures for the prevention (e.g., staff education on new policies) are determined. The final step in a root cause analysis is the implementation of these measures.

Key learning point: Root cause analysis is a retrospective method that investigates individual and system failures underlying medical errors and implements corrective measures to prevent their recurrence.

B) INCORRECT:

A retrospective cohort study is used to investigate the association between exposure and outcome and to calculate the relative risk of exposure. In this case, the association between the exposure (receiving a lower dose of preoperative antibiotics) and the outcome (SSI) could be studied retrospectively in two cohorts (i.e., exposed and not exposed). This analysis would help determine whether there is an association between receiving low dose antibiotics and developing an SSI, and could be an important step in evaluating what went wrong. However, this method does not address the question of how to prevent similar errors in the future, so a different analysis would be more appropriate.

C) INCORRECT:

A multilayered safety system, which references the Swiss cheese model, can help prevent potential mistakes by ensuring that if a hazard passes through a safeguard (hole), a subsequent layer (slice of cheese) can prevent its further passage through the system. In this case, the error has already occurred. A retrospective review is needed to first identify the cause to evaluate how a multilayered safety system should be structured or if it is even appropriate in this scenario.

D) INCORRECT:

A failure mode and effects analysis (FMEA) can help prevent future mistakes from occurring, but this is a prospective method (i.e., has the goal of anticipating potential future risks). In this case, the medical error has already occurred, so a prospective analysis would not be appropriate.
questions.hint: A retrospective method of error analysis would help identify the cause of the medical error and help prevent future recurrence.

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman who is receiving intravenous morphine via a patient-controlled pump and scheduled doses of intravenous hydromorphone reports uncontrolled pain 18 hours after undergoing an emergency laparotomy. The on-duty physician increases the dose of the scheduled intravenous hydromorphone and then signs out to the covering physician, letting the covering physician know the names of his patients, their locations, and the reasons for their admissions. Overnight, the patient continues to report uncontrolled pain, and the covering physician orders a one-time dose of intravenous hydromorphone. Shortly after the ward nurse administers the dose, the patient becomes confused, and her respirations decrease to 10/min. An iatrogenic opioid overdose is suspected. Which one of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this medical error?

choices.text: Nonstandardized patient handoff.
Fatigue of the covering physician.
Excessive workload of the covering physician.
Patient-controlled pump malfunction.
Accidental mix-up of drugs.

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Patient handoffs are used to communicate information between health care providers so that they have a shared understanding of the management of specific patients. Miscommunication during patient handoffs can ultimately result in errors that compromise patient safety. In this scenario, there was a change in the patient's medications (i.e., the increased dose of scheduled intravenous hydromorphone) that was not communicated to the covering physician. As a result, the patient received an inappropriate dose of additional intravenous hydromorphone, which led to an iatrogenic opioid overdose. Standardized handoffs (e.g., using checklists) have been shown to reduce the incidence of preventable medical errors. A proper handoff in this scenario should also include information about the patient's current medications (e.g., drug, route, amount, frequency, effectiveness), recent changes to management, and explicit suggestions for anticipated concerns (e.g., what to administer for this patient if she continues to have uncontrolled pain).

In patient handoffs, it is also important for the on-call physician to receive information on the patient's diagnoses, code status, a summary of the hospital course, and tasks to complete, and for there to be two-way communication between the physicians performing the handoff.

Key learning point: Structured handoff protocols that include current medication details, recent management changes, and anticipatory guidance significantly reduce miscommunication and prevent medication errors.

B) INCORRECT:

Physician fatigue can lead to inappropriate medical decision-making and medical errors. The initial response of the on-duty physician to increase the dose of the scheduled intravenous hydromorphone was appropriate for this patient's uncontrolled pain. The one-time dose ordered by the covering physician would also have been appropriate had the patient not recently received additional opioids. This should raise suspicion that the covering physician was lacking updated information about the patient's current medications.

C) INCORRECT:

Excessive physician workload can lead to inappropriate medical decision-making and medical errors. The initial response of the on-duty physician to increase the dose of the scheduled intravenous hydromorphone was appropriate for this patient's uncontrolled pain. The one-time dose ordered by the covering physician would also have been appropriate had the patient not recently received additional opioids. This should raise suspicion that the covering physician was lacking updated information about the patient's current medications. The covering physician deciding to get some sleep in case he has a busy night is inconsistent with his decision-making being negatively affected by an excessive workload.

D) INCORRECT:

Equipment malfunction is a relatively rare cause of medical error compared to other factors. Patient-controlled analgesia is an effective method for managing postoperative pain; there is no indication that a pump malfunction was the underlying cause of this medical error.

E) INCORRECT:

This patient presents with typical signs and symptoms of opioid overdose, which is consistent with her history of receiving multiple doses of intravenous morphine and hydromorphone. Accidental mix-up of drugs by the nurse is, therefore, unlikely. Moreover, hydromorphone would have been an appropriate choice of therapy had the patient not recently received additional opioids; there is no indication that the covering physician intended for a different drug to be administered.
questions.hint: Administration of an additional one-time dose of intravenous hydromorphone would have been an appropriate choice of therapy before the increase of the scheduled doses by the on-duty physician.

questions.text: A 32-year-old man is brought to the operating room to undergo a hip procedure. The anesthesiologist verifies the patient's name and date of birth. After general anesthesia is administered, the circulating nurse initiates a discussion among the surgeon, surgical physician assistant, anesthesiologist, and operating room technician. Each person actively communicates and agrees on the patient's identity, the surgical site, and the procedure. The circulating nurse then documents their conversation, and the surgeon marks the surgical site with his initials. After the surgery, the patient's wife asks the recovery room nurse why the bandaging is on her husband's left hip when his right hip was supposed to be operated on. A failure to perform which of the following actions most likely contributed to the error that occurred in this scenario?

choices.text: Involving the patient in the site verification process.
Using two unique patient identifiers.
Engaging in interprofessional communication.
Conducting a time-out immediately prior to surgery.
Marking an "X" on the left hip.

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Wrong-site surgery is a never event. The Universal Protocol, which is used to prevent wrong-site surgery, is a three-step process based on the human factors engineering strategy of redundancy and the Swiss cheese model for error prevention:

1. preprocedural verification of the patient's identity, surgical site, and surgical procedure;
2. surgical site marking;
3. performing a time-out.

The third step should take place in the operating room before the first incision and was performed correctly in this scenario. However, the first two steps should take place before the induction of anesthesia, in the preoperative or holding area, and, whenever possible, the patient should be actively involved. For operations in which wrong-site surgery is a concern (e.g., hip surgery), only the correct surgical site should be marked by writing the word “YES,” the attending surgeon's initials, or both using an indelible marker. Marking may be performed by the surgeon after verbal confirmation from the patient or by the patient directly in front of the surgeon, but the site marking protocol should be standardized for each institution.

Key learning point: Preoperative surgical site marking and verification, conducted before anesthesia with patient participation, prevent wrong-site surgery.

B) INCORRECT:

Using two unique patient identifiers before initiating any medical procedure is a crucial safety measure that helps prevent patient misidentification errors. In this scenario, the anesthesiologist used the patient's name and date of birth as identifiers, thereby fulfilling this requirement. The error that occurred in this scenario was wrong-site surgery rather than patient misidentification, which suggests that failure to perform a different safety measure contributed to the error.

C) INCORRECT:

Active interprofessional communication, in which disruptive behavior, environmental disturbance, hierarchy, language barriers, and multiple simultaneous conversations are avoided, is an important measure to ensure patient safety. Effective interprofessional communication was demonstrated in this scenario, as communication was initiated by the circulating nurse and involved the active contribution and agreement of all other members of the operating team. This suggests that failure to perform a different safety measure contributed to the error that occurred in this scenario.

D) INCORRECT:

A time-out is a break shortly before the initiation of an invasive medical procedure in which all team members confirm the patient's identity, the procedure, and the site. In this scenario, the time-out was performed correctly: it was initiated by the circulating nurse, covered all relevant points, involved active communication and the agreement of all team members, and was documented. This suggests that failure to perform a different safety measure contributed to the error that occurred.

E) INCORRECT:

The incorrect surgical site should not be marked; this includes marking with the word “NO” or an ambiguous visual cue (e.g., an “X” could also be interpreted as an indicator of the correct site). When marking the surgical site, the correct site should be marked by writing the word “YES,” the surgeon's initials, or both using an indelible marker. In this scenario, the surgeon correctly marked what he believed to be the surgical site with his initials. Incorrect site marking can be prevented by performing surgical site marking in the preoperative or holding area before the surgical time-out instead of in the operating room, as in this scenario.
questions.hint: The occurrence of wrong-site surgery can be decreased through active participation by all involved parties and consideration of all risk factors.

questions.text: A 68-year-old woman is admitted to the hospital because of acute congestive heart failure. She also has hypertension treated with lisinopril. When the physician responsible for the patient's care enters intravenous furosemide in the patient's orders, a clinical decision support system message appears on the computer saying that furosemide in combination with lisinopril may result in significant hypotension and decreased kidney function. The physician dismisses the message as one of the many inconsequential warnings that he encounters during his work. Two days after admission, the patient is diagnosed with type 2 myocardial infarction secondary to hypotension. A fishbone diagram is most likely to reveal which of the following as the root cause of the error that occurred in this scenario?

choices.text: Hindsight bias.
Adverse drug reaction.
Latent condition.
Physician burnout.
Alert fatigue.

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Hindsight bias, in the context of safety analysis, is the tendency to judge events that led to an outcome as having been more predictable than they actually were. In this case, the physician did not make a decision based on events that, at the time, could have been perceived as leading to a negative outcome.

B) INCORRECT:

An adverse drug reaction is an unintended and unpreventable drug event that occurs even though medication is administered appropriately. This patient, however, experienced a preventable drug interaction as a result of a medical error.

C) INCORRECT:

Latent conditions (or latent errors) are usually caused by system design or organizational issues, which is not the case in this scenario. Moreover, in this case, the medical error seems to be an active error because it is the result of direct contact between the physician and an aspect of the system, with an immediate impact on the patient.

D) INCORRECT:

Physician burnout is a reaction to occupational stressors, and it can cause medical errors. Symptoms include detachment, emotional exhaustion, and a decreased sense of accomplishment at work. Contrastingly, the interviews conducted as part of the root cause analysis revealed that the physician has a high level of engagement with patients and a strong sense of personal accomplishment from his work.

E) CORRECT:

Alert fatigue is the phenomenon of clinician desensitization to alarms. Although computerized alerts were created to improve patient safety, the high number of alarms encountered has led healthcare personnel to become desensitized to such warnings. This desensitization is worsened by the high proportion of alarms that are clinically inconsequential. As a result, physicians often ignore these warnings or do not react appropriately. In turn, as physicians start to ignore both meaningless and critical alarms, there are negative implications for patient safety because medical errors occur, like the one seen here where the physician ignored a computerized clinical alarm regarding a drug interaction.

Key learning point: Alert fatigue is clinician desensitization to frequent decision-support warnings, leading to ignored critical alerts and an increased risk of preventable medical errors.
questions.hint: Measures designed to improve patient safety can sometimes unintentionally result in medical errors.

questions.text: A 72-year-old woman is admitted to the hospital for carotid endarterectomy. A shared decision to perform right-sided carotid endarterectomy was made with consent from the patient's medical power of attorney, and the management plan was documented in the patient's records as “CEA right.” The surgical intern meets the patient on the ward on the day of surgery and, using a permanent marker, circles the surgical site and marks “X” on the nonsurgical site. The patient is brought to the operating room and the circulating nurse confirms that all relevant patient documents and findings are available. While the surgical team is scrubbing, the anesthetist asks the patient to verify her surgery site by pointing to it. Regional anesthesia is performed, and the patient is draped. The surgery is subsequently performed without any complications. While filling out the signout checklist after the surgery, the circulating nurse notices that the surgery was performed on the left carotid artery instead of the right. Which of the following actions would most likely have prevented this never event?

choices.text: Performing surgical site marking in the operating room
Providing the patient with a radiofrequency identification wrist band
Avoiding the use of abbreviations in patient records
Conducting a time-out immediately prior to surgery
Using adhesive tape for surgical site marking

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

It is generally recommended that surgical site marking be performed in the preoperative area, where there are fewer distractions compared to the operating room. Marking may be performed by the attending surgeon after verbal confirmation from the patient, although it is acceptable to delegate to another person who will also be present during the procedure (e.g., the surgical intern in this scenario), or by the patient directly in front of the surgeon, but the site marking protocol should be standardized for each institution.

B) INCORRECT:

Radiofrequency identification wrist bands can be used to verify a patient's identity and prevent errors caused by patient misidentification (e.g., wrong patient surgery). However, they are not typically used to identify surgical sites and it is unlikely that they would have prevented this patient's wrong-site surgery.

C) INCORRECT:

The use of nonstandardized abbreviations in documentation should be avoided to minimize errors. However, in this scenario, the procedure was documented as “CEA right” and correctly identified the laterality of the procedure.

D) CORRECT:

The Universal Protocol is a three-step process:

1. preprocedural verification of the patient's identity, the surgical site, and the surgical procedure;
2. surgical site marking;
3. performing a time-out.

A surgical time-out is performed in the operating room prior to the procedure to reconfirm the patient's identity, the procedure, and the surgical site. The time-out is typically initiated by a designated member of the team, such as the circulating nurse, and involves all of the team members (e.g., operating room technicians, principal surgeon, physician assistant) who are participating in the procedure. The whole team is responsible for reviewing all of the relevant information through active communication, and once everyone is in agreement, the time-out should be documented. A successful time-out requires a safety culture, which provides an environment in which health care providers can actively speak up about potential errors.

The protocol for surgical site marking was also not followed correctly in this scenario. When marking the surgical site, the correct site should be marked by writing the word “YES”, the surgeon's initials, or both using an indelible marker. The incorrect surgical site should not be marked; this includes marking with the word “NO” or an ambiguous visual cue (e.g., an “X” could also be interpreted as an indicator of the correct site).

E) INCORRECT:

The Joint Commission recommends making permanent surgical site markings to ensure that they are still visible following surgical preparation (e.g., antiseptic skin preparation and draping). Therefore, adhesive tape is not recommended because it can easily be rubbed off or transferred to a different site, which can result in wrong-site surgery.
questions.hint: The Universal Protocol should be followed to prevent never events such as wrong-site surgery. This protocol consists of a series of steps based on the human factors engineering strategy of redundancy and standardization and should be performed before invasive medical procedures. In this scenario, the surgeon did not follow the protocol for one of these steps correctly and a subsequent step was missed entirely. If this subsequent step had been performed, it could have reduced the likelihood of the error occurring by acting as an additional safety measure (i.e., a Swiss cheese model).

questions.text: A 74-year-old man comes to the office because of a 5-week history of fever, fatigue, and cough with purulent sputum. He has not seen a medical professional in 5 years. He appears thin. Chest x-ray shows a patchy infiltrate in the left lower lobe and ipsilateral hilar enlargement. Microscopic examination of the sputum reveals acid-fast bacilli. Polymerase chain reaction confirms the diagnosis of respiratory tuberculosis and the patient is placed in an airborne infection isolation room. A nurse and a physician associate student enter the patient's room to insert a urinary catheter. While preparing to insert the catheter, the student notices that the nurse has put on nonsterile gloves. Which of the following is the most appropriate reaction by the student?

choices.text: "I believe you accidentally put on the wrong gloves."
“I suggest we perform a root cause analysis to make sure this error does not happen again.”
“I am really sorry, but I have to report your mistake to the head nurse to ensure transparent communication.”
“Let’s go over everything again to make sure we did not forget something before we insert the catheter."
“Do you need any help with the insertion of the catheter?”

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Whenever a person witnesses a medical error, they should directly inform the health care provider who committed the error. This should be done politely and without regard for workplace hierarchy, interpersonal relationships, or the potential of a career setback. A witness who fails to act is also culpable for the consequences of the error. Early medical error reporting can offer a chance for rectification (e.g., replacing nonsterile gloves with sterile gloves) and prevent a near miss (e.g., break of sterile technique) from becoming an adverse event (e.g., catheter-associated urinary tract infection). Patient safety (nonmaleficence) is the foremost priority; a safety culture fosters the reporting of both active errors (as seen here) and latent errors.

B) INCORRECT:

Analysis of medical errors (e.g., root cause analysis) is in line with good safety culture and necessary to prevent future errors. However, a root cause analysis is performed after a procedure has been completed. Another reaction is more appropriate at this point in time.

C) INCORRECT:

It is necessary to report of medical errors (e.g., through an incident reporting system), and doing so is in line with good safety culture. However, reporting the error to the head nurse at this step in the procedure delays the possibility of rectifying the error and increases the risk that a near miss (e.g., break in sterile technique) becomes an adverse event (e.g., catheter-associated urinary tract infection). Furthermore, it is the responsibility of the person who committed the error to report it. It would be more appropriate for the student to give the nurse the chance to self report the error at a later time.

D) INCORRECT:

This statement does not directly address the problem that sterile technique has not been followed, which may convey the assumption that the procedure has not been compromised. Whenever a medical error is witnessed, the witness of the error should speak up. Addressing the error immediately makes rectification possible.

E) INCORRECT:

Collaboration across teams is necessary, and it is generally appropriate for the student to offer to help the nurse. However, urinary catheter insertion should be performed using sterile technique, which includes wearing sterile gloves. This nurse just put on nonsterile gloves. Any break in sterile technique jeopardizes patient safety and constitutes a medical error. Another reaction is more appropriate at this stage of the procedure.
questions.hint: Urinary catheter insertion is an aseptic procedure. Sterile technique, including wearing sterile gloves, should be maintained. Any break in the sterile field jeopardizes patient safety and constitutes a medical error.

questions.text: After a history of adverse outcomes in a small rural hospital, a quality and safety inspector is evaluating the communication between clinicians in the emergency department. A team of two physician assistants is responsible for patient care during the night. After their shift ends, a new team of three physician assistants takes over. The inspector is observing the transfer of patient information from the team of physician assistants working the night shift to the incoming day team. Which of the following is the most appropriate action during a handoff to ensure patient safety?

choices.text: Designate a single provider to be responsible for conducting the handoff
Conduct the handoff in a written format only
Request a read-back from the incoming team for all action items
Perform a detailed bedside round for each patient
Provide recommendations for anticipated events

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Designating a single provider to conduct the handoff is inappropriate because they may not have complete, up-to-date knowledge about the status of all patients. Any break in the continuity of care could cause harm to a patient. Therefore, all outgoing and incoming team members should attend the handoff.

B) INCORRECT:

Written communication (e.g., electronic health records, checklists, protocols) is used as a supportive tool during a handoff. However, conducting a handoff solely in a written format is inappropriate because verbal communication is necessary for asking questions, discussing uncertainties, and assessing the receiver's level of knowledge.

C) INCORRECT:

During a handoff, a read-back can ensure that the receiver has correctly understood the information given by the sender. However, a read-back should only be requested for critical items to ensure the timely transfer of high-priority information to the receiver.

D) INCORRECT:

Bedside handoffs may be necessary to discuss critically ill patients. However, because of the numerous distractions at the bedside, communication between clinicians may be interrupted, and relevant information could be missed. Handoffs should generally take place in a designated area free of nonemergency disturbances, allowing clinicians to focus on information transfer.

E) CORRECT:

During a handoff, the senders (the outgoing team) should prioritize communicating critical information, tasks (i.e., to-do items), and recommendations for anticipated events (i.e., if/then items) to the receivers (the incoming team). For example, “If the patient develops dyspnea, administer 40 mg of intravenous furosemide.” is an if/then item. Receivers should be able to ask questions and discuss uncertainties; therefore, handoffs should consist of verbal communication, preferably face-to-face, at a designated time and place free of nonemergency disturbances. Written communication (e.g., electronic health records, checklists, protocols) can be used as a complementary tool.

Standardized handoff communication tools (e.g., IPASS, SBAR) ensure consistency in the exchange of relevant patient information among clinicians.
questions.hint: During a handoff, information and responsibility for patient care are transferred from one team or physician assistant to another.

questions.text: A 62-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department of a busy suburban hospital because of a 1-week history of nausea and vomiting. She also has had intermittent fevers and headaches during the past 5 weeks. She does not have a stiff neck or sensitivity to light. She appears tired. Her temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 70/min, respirations are 15/min, and blood pressure is 135/85 mm Hg. She is alert and oriented to person, place, and time. Examination shows no abnormalities. A lumbar puncture is performed, and cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) is collected for analysis. On the way to the laboratory, the clinician loses the CSF specimens. The clinician decides that a repeat lumbar puncture should be performed. Before giving consent for the second procedure, the patient asks what the results are from the specimens obtained earlier. Which of the following responses is the most appropriate?

choices.text: "I sincerely apologize; I misplaced the specimens. Thankfully, this is not a big issue because I can easily obtain more fluid."
"I was unable to obtain results from the earlier tests because I misplaced the specimens. I sincerely apologize for the mistake."
"I was not able to get the answers we needed from the first set of tests, so we need to repeat them."
"Unfortunately, I was not able to get enough fluid in the specimens to perform the tests."
"I sincerely apologize; the lab seems to have lost the specimens I obtained earlier."
"There were just too many patients for us to keep track of today. I am so sorry, but I misplaced the specimens."
"Based on your symptoms, I think you might have chronic meningitis."

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Although this response does disclose that the clinician lost the specimens, it is inappropriate because it minimizes the gravity of the situation. Clinicians should disclose errors in objective terms and refrain from placing a value judgment on the significance of the error because each patient will have a unique response.

B) CORRECT:

This response is the most appropriate way of disclosing the medical error to the patient. Disclosure of medical errors involves clearly admitting the error, describing the nature of the error, and expressing personal regret or apology. Timely, full disclosure of errors is beneficial for the healthcare professional-patient relationship and patient safety.

C) INCORRECT:

This response is inappropriate because it fails to disclose that a medical error has occurred. In addition, it may mislead the patient into believing that the tests were performed but inconclusive.

D) INCORRECT:

This response is inappropriate because it fails to disclose that a medical error has occurred. In addition, it falsely claims that the CSF collected from the first lumbar puncture was inadequate.

E) INCORRECT:

Although this response does disclose that the specimens were lost, it is inappropriate because it falsely blames the laboratory. Optimal error disclosure involves clearly admitting that an error has occurred and truthfully stating the course of events that led to the error.

F) INCORRECT:

Although this response does disclose that the clinician lost the specimens, it is inappropriate because it makes an unprofessional excuse and implies that the error was unavoidable.

G) INCORRECT:

Although the patient's subacute development of nausea, vomiting, headache, and fevers is concerning for a diagnosis of chronic meningitis, this response is inappropriate because it fails to disclose that a medical error has occurred.
questions.hint: The loss of the first CSF specimens constitutes a medical error.

questions.text: A 36-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department after being involved in a motor vehicle collision. She was an unrestrained driver. She appears lethargic. Her temperature is 36.6°C (97.8°F), pulse is 78/min, and blood pressure is 110/72 mm Hg. A Focused Assessment with Sonography for Trauma scan of the abdomen shows free intraabdominal fluid, and the patient is taken to the operating room for an emergent laparotomy. A physician associate student, who is attempting to get a letter of recommendation from the head surgeon, joins the surgery.
